I'heatre Iloyaf, Drury ijrnie.
THIS EVENING, FEBRUARY 7, 1828,
UNDER THE DIRECTION OF
Mr. H. R. BISHOP,
WILL BE FEUrottMED
Handers Sacred Oratorio
THE
WITH
The additional Accompaniments by Mozart.
PART I. >
OVERTURE.
Recit. Mr. BRAHAM, “Comfort ye ray people.”
Air, “ Every valley shall be exalted."
Chorus, “ And the glory of the Lord.”
Recit. Mr. E. TAYLOR, “ Thus saith the Lqrd.”
Air, “ But who may abide the day of his coming." Chorus, “ And he shall purify."
Recit. Miss LOVE, “ Behold! a virgin.”
Air and Chorus, “ O thou that tellest.”
Recit. Mr. E. TAYLOR, “ For, behold ! darkness.” Air, “ The people that walked in darkness."
Grand Chorus, “ For unto us a Child is bom.”
PASTORAL SYMPHONY.
Recit. Miss BATON, “ There were shepherds.”
Chorus, “ Glory to God.”
Air, Miss PATON, “ Rejoice greatly.”
Recit. Miss LOVE, “ Then shall the eyes of the blind.” Air, “ He shall feed his flock.”
Air, Miss PATON, “ Come unto him."
Chorus, “ His yoke is easy.”
*	PART II.
Chorus, “ Behold the Lamb of God.”
Air, Miss LOVE, “ He was despised."
Chorus, “ Surely he hath borne our griefs.”
Recit. Mr. BRAHAM, “ All they that see him.”
Chorus, “ He trusted in God.”
Recit.Mr. BRAHAM, “Thy rebuke.”
Air, “ Behold, and see if there be any sorrow."
Recit. Madame CARADOR1 ALLAN, “ He was cut off.”
Air, “ But thou didst not leave.”
Semi-Chorus (the principal Singers), “ Lift up your heads. ” Recit. Mr. HORNCASTLE, “ Unto which of the angels.” Chorus, m Let all the angels."
Air, Mr. E. TAYLOR, “ Thou art gone up on high.”
Chorus, “ The Lord gave the word."	,
Air, Miss GRANT, “ How beautiful are the feet.”
Quartet,MissGRANT, Mr. ROBINSON, Mr.HORNCASTLE, and Mr. E. TAYLOR, & Chorus, “ Their sound is gone out." Air, Mr. E. TAYLOR, “Why do the nations."
Chorus, “ Let us break their bonds asunder.”
Recit. Mr. BRAHAM, “ He that dwelleth.”
Air, “ Thou shah break them.”
Grand Chorus, “ Hallelujah."
PART m.
Recit. Madame CARADORI ALLAN,
“ I know that my Redeemer liveth.”
Quartet (the principal Singers), “ Since by man came death.” Rccit. Mr. E. TAYLOR, “ Behold! I tell you a mystery." Air, u The trumpet shall sound.”	-
(Trumpet Obligato, Mr. E. HARPER.)
Recit. Miss LOVE, “ Then shall be brought to pass.”
Duet, Miss LOVE and Mr. HORNCASTLE, “ O death.” Chorus, “ But thanks be to God.”
Air, Miss GRANT, “ If God be for us."
Grand Chorus, “ Worthy is the lamb. Amen.”

Handers Sacred
HOP,
Oratorio
TH E
WITH
The additional Accompaniments by Mozart.
’ PART I.
OVERTURE.
lleCit. Mr. BRAHAM, “ Comfort ye my people.”
Air, “ Every valley *hall be exalted.”
Chorus, “ And the glory of the Lord.”
Recit. Mr. E. TAYLOR, “ Thus saith the Lord.”
Air, “ But who may abide the day of his coming.” Chorus, “ And he shall purify.”
Recit Miss LOVE, “ Behold! a virgin.”
Air and Chorus, “ O thou that tellest."
Recit. Mr. E. TAYLOR, “ For, behold ! darkness.” Air, “ The people that walked in darkness.”
Grand Chorus, “ For unto us a Child is born.”
PASTORAL SYMPHONY.
#
Recit Miss PATON, " There were shepherds.”
Chorus, “ Glory to God.”
Air, Miss PATON, “ Rejoice greatly."
Recit. Miss LOVE, “ Then shall the eyes of the blind.” Air, “ He shall feed his flock.”
Air, Miss PATON, “ Come unto him.”
Chorus, " His yoke is easy.”
PART II.
Chorus, Behold the Lamb of God.”
Air, Miss LOVE, “ He was despised.”
Chorus, “ Surely he hatli borne our griefs.”
Recit Mr. BRAHAM, “ All they that see him."	•
Chorus, “ He trusted in God.”
Recit. Mr. BRAHAM, “Thy rebuke."
Air, “Behold, and see if there lie any sorrow.”
Recit. Madame CARADORl ALLAN, “ He was cut off.”
Air, “ But thou didst not leave.”
Semi-Chorus (the principal Singers), “ Lift up your heads.' Recit. Mr. HORNCASTLF, “Unto which of'the angels." Chorus, ~ Let all the.angels."
Air, Mr. E. TAYLOR, “ Thou art gone up on high.’*
Chorus, “ The Lord gave the word.”
Air, Miss GRANT, “ How beautiful are the feet."
Quartet,MissGRANT, Mr. ROBINSON, Mr. HORNCASTLE, and Mr. E. TAYLOR, & Chorus, “ Tlieir sound is gone out.” Air, Mr. E. TAYLOR, “ Why do the nations.”
Chorus, “ Let us break their bonds asunder/’
Recit. Mr. BRAH AM, “ He that dwellcth."
Air, “ Thou shalt break them.”
Grand Chorus, “ Hallelujah.”
PART III.
Recit. Madame CARADORl ALLAN,
“ I know that my Redeemer liveth.”
Quartet (the principal Singers), “ Since by man came death.” Recit. Mr. E. TAYLOR, “ Behold! I tell you a mystery." Air, “ 'Che trumpet shall sound.”
.'Trumpet Obligato, Mr. HARPER)
Recit. Miss LOVE, “ Then shall be brought to pass.” Duet, Miss LOVE and Mr. HORNCASTLE, « O death.” Chorus, “ But thanks be to God,”
Air, Miss GRANT, " If God be for us.”
Grand Chorus, “ Worthy is the lamb. Amen.”

GOD SAVE THE KING. S Handel.
The Nobility, Gentry, and Public are most respectfully informed, that Handel’s Sacred Oratorio “ THE MESSIAH,” with the additional Accompaniments by Mozart, will be performed at the Theatre Royal, Covent Garden, on FRIDAY NEXT, March the l-Ith; being, in consequence of other arrangements POSITIVELY FOB THE LAST 1'IMK in the present season !

The Nobility, Gentry, and the Public, are most respectfully acquainted, that
This	Evening, May	24?/«, 1828,
THE USUAL
GRAND PERFORMANCE
Of Antient and Modern Music,
TO CONSIST OF
A POPULAR SELECTION
Will take place at this Theatre, under the immediate Direction of
Mr. H. R. BISHOP,
Who, in addition to the unprecedented Phalanx of Talent he has had the honour to present to the Public during the LENT Season, is enabled, by the most liberal kindness, to announce the following valuable assistance :

NO ORDERS whatever can be admitted—and the FREE LIST, on this oooasion, must of necessity be entirely suspended.
#>• The Theatrical Orchestra will be added to the Pit for the accommodation of the Public.
Placet in the Boxes, or Private Boxes, may be taken at the Box Office of the Theatre.

The DOORS will be opened at Half-past Six, and the Performance commence at Seven o’clock.

NO ORDERS whatever can be admitted—and the FREE LIST, on this occasion, must of necessity be entirely suspended.
13“ The Theatrical Ochestra will be added to the Pit for the accommodation of the Public» .Applications for Places in the Boxes are, in order to prevent the disappointments which have lately occurred at Concerts, Spc. most respectfully entreated to be made as early as possible.
Places in the Boxes, or Private Boxes, may be taken at the Box Office of the Theatre.

Theatre Royal, Drury Dane.
IN reply to a statement contained in “ The Morning Journal” of yesterday,
l Certify, that no Gasometer, Chamber, or receptacle for GAS, is now, or ever has been, placed within the walls of Drury-Lane Theatre I but l^at th(*se Parts of the Theatre, at present lighted with Gas, are supplied from the Main of the Chartered Gas Company, which leads through Russell-slrect; and, upon the same principle, the Chartered Company are now employed to light a portion of Covent Garden Theatre.
I beg leave to add, that the King's Theatre, the Adelphi, and English Opera House, are also supplied from the Mains of the above Company.
JOHN EVANS,
Supenntcudant of thft Chartered Ga< Light nml Coke Comp.anv, Horseferry Road, Westmior- r.

IN reply to a statement contained in. “ The Morning Journal’' of Tuesday
i Certify, that no Gasometer, Chamber, or receptacle for GAS is now, or ever has been, placed within the walls of Drurv-
Lane Theatre | but that those parts of the Theatre, at present lighted with Gas are supplied from the Main of the Chartered Gas Company, which leads through RuiseU-street; and, upon the same principle, the Chartered Company are now employed to light a portion of Covent Ga> den Theatre.	S
1 beg leave to add, that the King's Theatre, the Adelphi, and English Opera House, are also supplied from the Mains of the above Company.
JOHN EVANS,
Sapen.itend.nt of the Chartered Gw Light and Coke Company Horseferry Bead, Westminster

ORATORIOS.
The Public is respectfully informed that, in consequence of Mr. COLMAS's having asserted a rizht (as the Lard Chamberlain' Examiner of all “ Entertainments of the Stage’') to peruse and licence the new Oratorio of JOSEPH, announced for performance this ’veiling, Mr. HAWES, as Conductor of the Oratoi ios and Coticerts to be given during the approaching Lent Season, has determined to with-lraw the above-named Oratorio, until the lit. Hon. the LORD CH \MBERLAIN shall have decided whether this unprecedented exaction iy Mr. Colman (which, if submitted to, mould entail an almost incalculable expense in FEES on him and all future Conductors of such Performances) ix authorised by the Act of Parliament 10th George II. Under these circumstances, the First Part of LIa YDn's Oratorio of he CREATION mill be substituted.
The Nobility, Gentry, and Public, are most respectfully informed that the Grand Performances of .Antient and Modern Music
will commence

ORATORIOS.
The Nobility, Gentry, and the Public, are most respectfully informed that
HANDEL'S SACRED ORATORIO THE
MESSIAH
WILL BE PERFORMED, AT THE
Theatre	Royal, Drury	,
This Evening, Wednesday, March 11, 1829,
UNDER THE SOLE MANAGEMENT AND DIRECTION OF
Mr. MAWIX
PART I.
OVERTURE.
Recitative, Mr. BRAHAM, “Comfort yc my people.”
Air, “ Every valley shall be exalted."
Chorus, “ And the glory of the I.ord.”
Recitative, Mr. E. SEGUIN, “ l hus saith the Lord.”
Air, “ But who may abide the day of his coming."
Chorus, “ And he shall purify."
Recitative, Miss LOVE, “Behold! a virgin.”
Air and Chorus, “ Oh, thou that tellest."
Recitative, Mr. J. O. ATKINS, “ For, behold! darkness,” Air, “ The people that walked in darkness."
Grand Chorus, “ For unto us a Child is born."
PASTORAL SYMPHONY.
lecitative, Miss BETTS, “ There were shepherds.” horus, “ Glory to God.” ir, Miss BETTS, “ Rejoice greatly.”
Recitative, Miss LOVE, “ Then shall the eyes of the blind.” Air, “ He shall feed his flock."
Air, Maaame STOCKHAUSEN, “ Come unto him.” Chorus, “ His yoke is easy.”
PART II.	•
Chorus, “ Behold the Lamb of God.”
Air, Miss LOVE, “ He was despised.”
Chorus, “ Surely he hath borne our griefs.”
Recitative, Mr. BRAHAM, “ All they that see him.”
Chorus, “ He trusted in God.”
Recitative, Mr. BRAHAM, “ Thy rebuke.”
Air, “ Behold and see if there be any sorrow.”
Recitative, Miss FARRAR, “ He was cut off."
Air, “ But thou didst not leave his soul in hell.”
Semi-Chorus (the Principal Singers), “ Lift up your heads.” Recitative, Mr HORNCASTLE, “ Unto which of the angel*.” Chorus, “ Let all the angels.”
Air, Mr. CHAPMAN, “ Thou art gone up on high.”
Chorus, “ The Lord gave the word.”
Air, Miss BETTS, “ How beautiful are the feet”
Quartet, Miss FARRAR, Mr. EVANS,
Mr. HORNCASTLE, and Mr. CHAPMAN, an«] Chore*,
“ Their sound is gone out.”
Air, Mr. J. O. ATKINS, “ Why do the nations."
Chorus, “ Let us break their bunds asunder."
Recitative, Mr. BRAHAM, “ He that dwelleth.”
Air, “ Thou shalt break them.”
Grand Chorus, “ Hallelujah.”
BETWEEN THE FIRST AND SECOND PARTS,	1
HANDEL’S FIRST GRAND CONCERTO.
BETWEEN THE SECOND AND THIRD PARTS,
A Concerto on the Violin by Mr. OURY.
PART III.
Air, Madame STOCKHAUSEN, “ 1 know that my Redeemer.” Quartet (the Principal Singers), “Since by man came death.” Recitative. Vlr. J. O. ATKINS, “Behold! I tell you a mystery.” Air, “ The trumpet shall sound.”
(Trumpet Obligato, Mr. HARPER.)
Recitative, Miss LOVE, “ Then shall be brought to pas*." Duet, Miss LOVE and Mr. HORNCASTLE, “O .>eath.\ Chorus, “ But thanks be to God.”
Air, Master SMITH, “ If God be for us.”
Grand Chorus, “ Worthy is the Lamb. Amen.”
PRINCIPAL VOCAL PERFORMERS.
Miss LOVE and Miss BETTS,
Miss FARRAR,	Master SMITH,
AND
Madame STOCKHAUSEN.
Mr. BRAHAM,
Mr. HORNCASTLE,	Mr. EVANS,
Mr. CHAPMAN, Mr. HOBBS, Mr. BOND,
Mr. E. SEGUIN' and Mr. J. O. ATKINS.
(Pupil of tht Royal AcuUnty of Music,)
Leader, Mr. WEICHSEL. Organ, Mr. T. ADAMS.
The Chorus will be numerous and complete, assisted by the Young Gentlemen of His Majesty’s Chapel lloyal and St. Pan '*
Cathedral, and under the superintendence of Mr. J. T. HARRIS.
Places in the Eoxes may be taken at the Pox Office of the Theatre.—Book* of the Performance may be had in the Theatre, prioc Tenpenoe.
Boxes, 7s—Pit. 3«. 6d—Lower Gallery, 2s—Upper Gallery, Is—Second Price at Nine.
(3* It is particularly requested that Parties wishing for Private Boxes will make their application at the Box Office of the Theatre.
The DOORS will be opened at Half-past Six, and the Performance commence at Seven o'clock.
A Course of Six Lectures on Music will be delivered by Mr. T. Adams, with copious illustrative Performances on the Apollonicoo. pnmmenrinv on Thursday, the 13th of March. 1830. at two o’clock, and to be continued on each succeeding Thursday, at the Room a
Theatre Royal, Ilrury Lane.

MESSIAH

PROGRAMME.
DOORS OPEN AT TEN O’CLOCK PRECISELY.
Coachmen to set down with their Horses’ Heads towards the Strand.
A MILITARY BAND will be stationed in THE ROTUNDA.
QUARTER PAST TEN O’CLOCK.
THE CONCERT.
ELEVEN O’CLOCK.
THE N E W______B ALLET.
LITOLFl BAND,

YariGriuochi Di Destrezza!
GRAND FANTOCCINI.
AT INTERVALS.
Adams* Band for Country Dances.
THROUGHOUT THE EVENING.
QUARTER PAST TWELVE O’CLOCK.
Juan DecastrooatheCordeYolante
AT IIALF-PAST TWELVE O’CLOCK.
A MAGNIFICENT BALLOON
AND PARACHUTE,
Will traverse the Stage, an«!, at a certain signal, disperse amid the Company Showers of BON BON and CON KIT C It E, prepared by Mr. Grogan, fonfertioi er.
THE GItA\D §ALOO\,
Calculated to hold 1000 Persons, will be filled up in elegant style, und op, nut as
THE SUPPER ROOM,
PRECISELY AT ONE O’CLOCK.
THE PIT w*N be covered ever, and united to the extensive Stage, forming ONE GRAND ARENA,
Ornamented with Trophies, Emblems, Banners, Transparencies, Devices, ire. SPLENDIDLY ILLUMINATED
With Variegated Lamps, Chinese lanterns, Candelabra, Girandoles, ire.
The whole of the Arrangements will be under the superinlendanrt of
Mr. W. BARRYMORE.

Supper Tickets, Seven Shillings and Sixpence each, to be had of Mr. Charles Wright, and at the Box-Office.

On WEDNESDAY NEXT, the 12th of MARCH, 1828,
(In compliance with a desire which has been very generally expressed)
THE PERFORMANCE WILL CONSIST OF A GRAND
Miscellaneous Selection of Music
FROM THE WORKS OP

MR. H. R. BISHOP.

____________________________GOD SAVE THE KING, S Handel-______________________
The Nobility, Gentry, and Public are most respectfully informed, that Handel’s Sacred Oratorio “ THE MESSIAH,” with the additional Accompaniments by Mowirt, will be performed at the Theatre Royal, Covent Garden, on FRIDAY NEXT, March the 14th ; being, in consequence of other arrangements, POSITIVELY FOR THE LAST TIME in the present season!

GOD SAVE THE KING. S Handel.
The Nobility, Gentry, and Public are most respectfully informed, that Handel’s Sacred Oratorio “ THE MESSIAH," with the additional Accompaniments by Moaart, will be performed at the Theatre Royal, Covent Garden, on FRIDAY NEXT, March the 11th ; being, in consequence of other arrangements, POSITIVELY FOR THE LAST TIME in the present season!
